author: monkeyontheloose1301
content: If i run a validator node and then it goes offline for a while, will it get punished?

author: monkeyontheloose1301
content: Also I heard that your not going to fully slashed if you sign twice but the attack is not coordibated, what is that about?

author: benjaminion
content:
(1) If you are offline then your penalty is about the same as the reward you could have made. So being up >50% of the time means you don't lose stake in the long run (roughly).

(2) If many people are offline (>1/3 of validators) and the chain stops finalising, you get an extra penalty for being offline, which gets big over time.

(3) If only you are slashed then you lose 1 Eth and get kicked out. If many people are slashed around the same time, the punishment is bigger, up to the full 32 Eth.

hth.

content: Can the withdrawal key get someone out of validating?

author: benjaminion
content: Validating uses your signing key. You can cease validating at any time by exiting. That does not require the withdrawal key, only your signing key. Once you are out, that validator cannot be restarted. At some point after exiting you will want to release your stake - this requires your withdrawal key. But there are no withdrawals in Phase 0 or Phase 1 at least.

author: monkeyontheloose1301
content: Can the withdrawal key cease the validating?

author: benjaminion
content: No. You need a exit message signed by the normal signing key. There has been some discussion about this, but no changes resulted. If you have custody of the withdrawal key, and some staking platform has the signing key, then you should demand a pre-signed exit message from them to protect yourself in case they perform badly.

author: benjaminion
content: In principle, yes. But you'd need some guarantee that they used the same key to sign the deposit. I haven't thought much about what workflows around this would look like. They could send you both the withdrawal and the signed deposit data, and you could make the deposit yourself after verifying they both match the same pubkey (and the withdrawal key that you hold: the first step would be you sending them the withdrawal hash so they can make the deposit data). That should work.
